item.title: Air-gapped GitOps with OCM & Flux
item.description: Introduction In this guide, we will show how the tools provided by OCM make it possible to automate your air-gapped deployments.

item.title: Best Practices
item.description: This chapter contains guidelines for common scenarios how to work with the Open Component Model. Separate between Build and Publish Building multi-arch images Using Makefiles Prerequisites Templating the resources Pipeline integration Static and Dynamic Variable Substitution Debugging: Explain the blobs directory Self-contained transport archives CICD integration Separate between Build and Publish Typical automated builds have access to the complete internet ecosystem.

item.title: Build & Deploy Infrastructure via Helm Charts with OCM
item.description: Introduction Let’s illustrate a very simple “Hello World” example application and show how to leverage OCM to build an application component containing a Helm Chart and an OCI Image and deploy it to a local kind k8s cluster.

item.title: Create an OCM component for a simple application
item.description: Introduction Let’s build an OCM component for a simple application, containing a Helm Chart and an OCI Image. We use the chart and image from Stefan Prodan’s podinfo as example.

item.title: Deployment scenario using an aggregate(d) component
item.description: Prerequisite We assume that the reader has already read all the previous guides in the component area. This guide discusses a more complex scenario using plain Localizations and Configurations without the use of Unpacker.

item.title: Deploying Applications with OCM & GitOps
item.description: Introduction This tutorial will demonstrate how to get started deploying applications using the Open Component Model & Flux. In this guide we will leverage Flux and the ocm-controller to deploy an existing component to a Kubernetes cluster.

item.title: GitOps Driven Configuration of OCM Applications
item.description: Introduction This guide is the final part of our series exploring OCM, the ocm-controller and how to drive GitOps processes using OCM as the source of truth.
